   INTERNATIONAL

   CUBA-EMBARGO-$ADV24 _ VARADERO, Cuba _ The U.S. Congress has
moved closer to easing the Cuban embargo, giving initial passage to
measures that would allow the sale of food and medicine to Cuba, as
well as a bill that would ease travel restrictions that currently
bar most U.S. citizens from visiting Cuba. If the latter measure
wins final approval, it could prove a bonanza for the Cuban tourism
industry, which has grown dramatically in the past decade.
(Williams, Cox News Service). WITH PHOTO.

   WAN: Location, Atlanta, International, Other.

   Expected to move Thursday on the NYT wire in both International
and Financial categories.

   WITH

   CUBA-JOURNAL _ VARADERO, Cuba _ A golf vacation in Cuba: Now
there's a contradiction in terms for many baby-boomers, who spent
their elementary school years in the 1960s ducking under their
desks for nuclear attack drills during the Cuban missile crisis.
But the land that once threatened us with Russian nukes has built
its first modern 18-hole golf course at the tourist resort of
Varadero, and hopes Americans will soon be playing the sport of
capitalist bankers on its socialist shores. We play a round and
reflect on the study in contrasts that is modern Cuba. (Williams,
Cox News Service) WITH PHOTOS.

   EDS: This foreign journal can twin with CUBA-EMBARGO.

   CHINA-SEX _ BEIJING _ Prostitution is rampant in China. From the
biggest cities to the smallest towns, from the toniest hotels to
the seediest roadside stalls, women are making a living with their
bodies. Experts say it is one of the major reasons for a
skyrocketing number of cases of syphilis, gonorrhea and other
sexually transmitted diseases (STDs). Although the government is
starting to recognize the seriousness of the problem, few believe
it will be brought under control anytime soon. With an ever-more
mobile population, a dismal level of sex education for young people
who are becoming increasingly sexually active and a sex industry
that is almost institutionalized, government efforts to limit the
spread of STDs seem like a drop in the bucket. (Chao, Cox News
Service) WITH PHOTOS

   SEIRRALEONE _ Greenville, N.C., families urge Congress to visit
with delegation coming from civil war-torn Seirra Leone. The
delegation, including several children, are coming to the U.S. next
week to urge the U.S. to send troops to that country to stop the
war. One of the locals is a new citizen who's working the
democratic process to raise awareness about the war. A good subplot
is that he is acting on his citizenship more than many of us here
who are natives. (Greenville Daily Reflector)

   NATION

   FLOOD _ Greenville N.C.'s Neighborhood Services division wants
owners of flood damaged property to clean up their lots. A lot of
neighbors who have fixed up their homes are complaining about the
mess. Many offenders are awaiting buyout funds. Should they be
forced to clean up property that's in limbo because of the slow
wheels of government? (Greenville Daily Relector) WITH PHOTO

   CHARTER-SCHOOLS _ WASHINGTON _ Charter schools have crossed the
threshold from ``experimental'' to a real educational phenomenon.
There has been a sharp increase in the number of charter schools
and many more are in the works. Still, they represent only one of
every 45 schools and the jury is out on whether they provide a
better education. Plus, there's heated discussion over who should
license and licensing standards. (Mollison, Cox News Service) WITH
PHOTOS.

   WITH

   CHARTER-WHAT _ A box defining charter schools, vouchers, etc.

   CHARTER-Q&A-PRO _ A brief Q&A with a leading proponent of
charter schools.

   CHARTER-Q&A-CON _ A brief Q&A with a leading opponent of charter
schools.

   CHARTER-DATA _ Graphics material. Moving Wednesday.

   WAN: Atlanta, National, Education

   BEARS-MAIN _ GRAND JUNCTION, Colo. _What is the outlook for
bears this winter? Are we going to see a lot of dead bears? What is
it about habitat conditions and human development that have lead to
so many confrontations this year? If the weather had been the way
it was suppose to be, could we still have so many contacts? What
will the longer-term effects on bear population from this summer?
How does this compare with 1977? How does our area compare with
other parts of the state this summer? (Grand Junction)

   WITH

   BEARS-STRIKES _ GRAND JUNCTION, Colo. _ In times like this, is
the two-strikes rule fair? Don't the bears deserve some slack
before they are destroyed? Is 2-strikes good wildlife management?
(Grand Junction)

   WITH

   BEARS-PEOPLE _ GRAND JUNCTION, Colo. _ What should people do?
Should people feed the bears? What security precautions as they
hunt, hike, go to school, etc. this fall. (Grand Junction)

   VOTERS-UNINFORMED _ WASHINGTON _ In a survey of college
freshean, the New York Times found ``a striking ingorance of even
the most elementary aspects'' of U.S. politics. The year was 1943.
More than half a century later, amid the ongoing information boom,
social scientists say little has changed. American voters are
disturbingly ignorant about the country's political life and its
leaders. Even in the age of radio talk shows and Internet chat, a
majority of Americans have trouble identifying their congressman or
naming specific policy details of the presidential candidates. A
look at the phenomenon and its impact of voter apathy and turnout.
(Holmes, Cox News Service)

   WITH

   UNINFORMED-POLLS _ A look at polling data on what Americans do
and do not know about politics and elected officials.

   Moving Wednesday in (w) Washington and (p) politics categories.

   WAN: Atlanta, National, Politics

   GATEWAY _ SAN DIEGO _ Gateway Inc., the computer maker with the
boxes designed to look like dairy cows, is about to become a
maverick in the stampede of companies selling Internet-ready
machines. When Gateway introduces the first of its so-called
Internet appliances in coming months, it will market them not as
alternatives to traditional PCs, but as add-ons to users' existing
home computers. (Keefe, Cox News Service). WITH PHOTOS

   WITH

   GATEWAY-PLAN _ Here's a peek at the new Internet-ready computers
that San Diego-based Gateway Inc. plans to introduce. (Keefe, Cox
News Service)

   (For Atlanta) TECH-GADEL _ WASHINGTON _ As high-tech companies
mushroom, Georgia's old economy - largely built on peanuts, poultry
and pulp wood - is being transformed. The new foundation rests on
computer bits, bytes and biotech. While only about 4 percent of
Georgians are farmers today, about 7 percent are high-tech workers,
such as computer engineers and programmers. In metro Atlanta alone,
roughly 10,000 tech companies employ about 220,000 people. But
while the tech sector is driving up the state's population and
wealth, Georgia's 13-member delegation to Congress remains outside
the inner circles of tech political power. Though they won't speak
on the record, many of Georgia's business executives and lobbyists
grumble about their lawmakers' lackluster leadership on tech
issues. (Geewax, Cox News Service)

   With TECH-VOTE _ How the Georgia delegation voted on granting
permanent normal trade relations to China.

   Story moved Sept. 13; data to move after Senate vote on China.

   WAN: Atlanta, Business, Technology

   POL-TICKER _ A brief roundup of the day's campaign events,
pulled from Cox staff and wire reports. (Cox News Service) ETA: 9
p.m.

   BUSINESS

   EXPERIENCE _ How are you supposed to get experience when no one
will hire you because you lack experience? We'll talk to employment
experts about strategies for getting around this age-old career
Catch-22. (Mallory, Atlanta Journal-Constitution) WITH PHOTO

   OPTIONS _ One out of five American workers _ clerks and assembly
line workers as well as white-collar executives _ are eligible for
stock options. Would you believe stock options for everybody on the
assembly line at Ford plants and behind the counters at Starbucks?
The trend is driven by business necessities, including a tight
labor market and global competition. Top-five executives still get
a third of all options granted, but options are becoming a bigtime
benefit for workaday Americans, too. (Ezell, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution)

   BLACKS-STOCKS _ Black investors are getting less timid about
investing in stocks, says mutual fund executive Mellody Hobson. In
a Q&A, she she talks about why African-Americans have been
super-cautious and why that's beginning to change. (Ezell, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution) WITH PHOTO

   FLIGHT-SERV _ When Todd Bottorff was brought in to help pull
Flightserv.com out of its dive in late May, he faced some
Internet-sized challenges. The Atlanta company's stock had dropped
90 percent from its 52-week high, after ranking as Georgia's
best-performing stock last year. A New York money manager had
cancelled the second half of a $10 million investment. Few business
travelers were using Flightserv's Web site, www.flightserv.com.,
which offers individual seats on private jet flights between
Atlanta and New York. And the company was running out of cash. So,
over the next several weeks, Flightserv's new president and chief
operating officer cut the staff and marketing budget and suspended
flights. Bottorff also plunged into retooling Flightserv's business
model and rounding up new investors and business partners.
(Grantham, Atlanta Journal-Constitution)

   WITH

   FLIGHT-SIDE _ A history of the shell company that became
Flightserve. (Grantham, Atlanta Journal-Constitution)

   OPED/EDITORIAL

   GARCIA-COLUMN _ Political memories are notoriously short, a
Republican friend reminded me during a conversation about Gov.
George W. Bush's current situation. After the primaries,
experienced politicos never expected the race to be anything other
than close. But then Bush caught a good bounce after the Republican
convention in Philadelphia and suddenly was portrayed as inevitable
in the national press, which now leads to stories about how badly
the campaign is stumbling. (Garcia, Austin American-Statesman)

   KLEINBERG-COLUMN _ MIAMI _ If you leave by speedboat from the
environs of Havana and set a course due north, you'll shortly reach
one of an atoll-like group of uninhabited islands called the
Marquesas Keys. They are part of the United States, between Key
West and the Dry Tortugas. You land there, you're in America.
You've succeeded, according to Bill Clinton's controversial wet
foot/dry foot Cuban Adjustment Act, in reaching our shores and
almost assuredly will not be repatriated. Therefore, more and more
are headed for the Marquesas as that is the shortest distance
between Cuba and the United States, about 80 miles. (Kleinberg, Cox
News Service.) MOVES THURSDAY.

   GLASS-COLUMN _ WASHINGTON _ If the Texas governor were running
for ``Mr. Nice Guy,'' you would have to grade his effort as an
``A,'' as in affable, amenable, amiable and amicable. But is that
an adequate argument to assume the presidency in 2001? Once, Bush
glowed in the aura of an invincible winner. But that ended in the
dog days of August and it's unlikely to return even if he manages,
against high odds, to stitch together the 270 electoral votes he
needs to win. (Glass), Cox News Service).

   Moving in (k) comnmentary and (p) politics categories.

   WAN: Atlanta, Op-Ed and Editorial, Columns/Commentary(Andy Glass
is a columnist for Cox News Service in the Washington bureau.)
MOVES THURSDAY.

   LIFESTYLE

   ELECTRIC-POOCH _ Electronic puppies won't shed, won't bite,
won't chase cars and if you forget to take them out for a walk they
won't do anything unpleasant on the floor. Several toy makers
apparently think interactive electronic puppies are going to be the
next big fad for kids, and they've rushed quite a few models onto
toy department shelves this year. (Cummings, Dayton Daily News)

   SAVING-CAVES _ Rusty's Cave is as quiet as a tomb and as artful
as a museum. As long as the clumsy, the malevolent or the profane
don't stumble upon it, it's safe. For Rusty's, while not a secret,
is not well known, which has protected the formations growing from
the floor and the ceiling. They took thousands of years to form.
They can shatter in seconds. In the darkness, Diane Cousineau of
Lafayette and Bill Putnam of Lawrenceville murmur about enjoying
quiet moments in the cool embrace of the earth. ``You know how some
people are beautiful and stunning and others are just as plain as
plain can be?'' Cousineau says. ``Caves are like that too. Every
one is different.'' Putnam is a director the Atlanta-based
Southeastern Cave Conservancy Inc., which Cousineau chairs. For the
past several years, the 600-member organization has rapidly
acquired caverns from West Virginia to Florida both to hold and to
protect. Most are near Tennessee-Alabama-Georgia border, a region
with perhaps more caves per square mile than anywhere in the United
States. ``Land acquisition is our mission,'' says Cousineau. ``We
just need to go out and buy most of the Southeast. It's a modest
goal.'' (Visser, Atlanta Journal-Constitution) WITH PHOTOS

   KOA _ BELTON, Texas _ Who stays at the KOA these days? What's
the scene there like? We spend a Saturday at one and find the
answers. (Robbins, Austin American-Statesman) WITH PHOTOS MOVED.

   TOASTMASTERS _ is attracting more diverse members than the
stereotypical businessmen in suits. Just about the only thing
Toastmasters all have in common anymore is the desire to be better
speakers. (Grand Junction) WITH PHOTOS MOVED.

   WITH

   TOASTMASTERS-SIDE _ First person account of the Toastmasters
experience. (Grand Junction) MOVED.

   CoxNet LIFESTYLES: HOME & GARDEN_ (EDS: This is the CoxNet
Lifestyles page for the current week. This layout is now
available.)

   Coxnet LIFESTYLES 0923: FALL GARDENING -- Fall, the best
gardening season of all, is officially here _ so get organized.
True, spring holds lots of promise for gardeners, avid and amateur
alike. But autumn gives many plants their best shot at success
because they'll have all winter to rest up before they're forced to
battle the summer stresses of heat, drought, insects and disease.
(Flanders, Atlanta Journal-Constitution). Art includes a 4-column
color photo of a fall garden next to a house.

   WITH: GARDENING CHART -- A chart showing gardening tasks that
need to be preformed in September and October. Art includes seven
1-column color photos.

   WITH: FURNACE UPDATE -- To those conscientious folks who are
never late with an oil change, who have a complete physical every
year and who keep track of everybody's birthday, this is a gentle
reminder: It's time to think about scheduling your annual furnace
inspection and cleaning. (Cummings, Dayton Daily News)

   TRAVEL

   COXNET TRAVEL _ (EDS: This is the CoxNet Travel page for the
current week. This layout is now available.)

   TRAVEL-FIRSTCOAST _ That well-traveled ribbon of asphalt known
as A1A _ which follows Florida's Atlantic coastline south all the
way to Key West _ takes on a different identity between Amelia
Island and St. Augustine. Here, the highway is known as the
Buccaneer Trail, and it makes a beeline into the past. The 52-mile
route where pirates, explorers and early settlers once roamed is as
scenic as it is historic. Florida's northeastern coast - including
the booming city of Jacksonville 10 miles inland on the St. Johns
River - offers Atlantans many vacation options within an easy drive
of each other. (Thrasher, Atlanta Journal-Constitution)

   WITH

   TRAVEL-FIRSTCOASTTOUR _ Four days on the First Coast: A ramble
along the historic Buccaneer Trail from Amelia Island to St.
Augustine takes visitors through the land that once was the domain
of native tribes, explorers, early settlers and pirates. Plus, a
sidetrip off the trail to the booming city of Jacksonville.
(Thrasher, Atlanta Journal-Constitution)

   TRAVEL-FLA-DRIVES _ A short on ``Worth the Drive,'' a free,
84-page guide published by Visit Florida (the state's tourism
promotions agency), featuring driving tours of 10 regions, as well
as theme tours that focus on ethnic heritage and outdoor adventure.
(Hamilton, Atlanta Journal-Constitution)

   WITH

   TRAVEL-FLORIDA-WEB _ Here are helpful Web sites to plan a
Florida trip, including www.flausa.com, an extensive and
well-organized site maintained by Visit Florida, the state's
official tourism promotion agency. (Hamilton, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution)

   TRAVEL-TIPS _ Going Places _ Paula Crouch Thrasher's weekly
column of travel news, notes and tips. (Thrasher, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution)

   TIME-SHARE _ It can be hard to say no to a timeshare salesman.
You are spending a weekend, gratis, at a resort, sometimes with
spending money or half-price Disney World or dinner theater tickets
thrown in to boot. There is an obligation to at least listen to the
presentation, and the salesmen have a quick retort for every reason
not to buy. But the salesmen probably never mention the inevitable
day when you try to sell the timeshare. Then you may find that your
vacation adventure has turned into a financial nightmare. The
Internet, however, is providing some relief. (Beasley, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution)

   ALABAMA _If you've been through Birmingham lately, you might
have noticed something odd about the skyline. Vulcan has vamoosed.
The cast-iron statue that for six decades crowned the ridge
overlooking downtown has been dismantled for safety reasons. Like
Humpty Dumpty, the Roman god of the forge sits in pieces behind a
fence in Vulcan Park, awaiting the funds to repair his parts and
put him back together again. ``It's got to be the world's largest
derriere,'' says Stewart Dansby, executive director of the Vulcan
Park Foundation, mentioning the bare metal bum that has spawned
many a joke and ``Buns of Iron'' T-shirt. ``We've had more than one
person kiss it.'' Must be an Alabama thing. (Auchmutey, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution)

   FASHION

   FASHION-PLAIDS _ Great Scot! Plaids are back, but with a
decidedly updated look. From prim and proper to hip and funky,
unusual colors give the traditional preppy pattern a new edge.
Think teal blue with brown, chartreuse with olive, orange with
purple. (Johnson, Atlanta Journal-Constitution) WITH PHOTOS

   SCIENCE/MEDICINE

   FERTILITY _ Recent birth of sextuplets in Greenville, N.C.,
focuses international debate about the use of fertilty drugs in
eastern North Carolina. What medical experts, religious leaders,
academic authorities _ and hopefully the parents _ think about the
fertility drug pros and cons. The growing use of such drugs is
increasing the chances of multiple births like the once here, in
Iowa and Italy. Do such pregnancies unnecessarily risk the babies'
lives? Do they place unnecessary financial and emotional strain on
the families and communities that support them? Are such risks and
strains acceptable in the face of infertility? (Greenville Daily
Reflector)

   POLIO _ This summer, world health officials - including the CDC
- acknowledged they would not meet an oft-stated goal of ridding
the world of polio by the end of this year. Next week, (Sept. 27),
many of those officials leading the fight will join Ted Turner and
other big spenders who are helping to fund the effort, in a ``polio
summit'' to explore why the fight is not being won on time. The NYC
meeting is intended to redirect attention away from the
public-health failure and focus media attention on the last push to
eradicate polio - which WHO hopes to accomplish shortly. To set up
the conference, we take a look at why 15-20 of the 30 countries
which had polio at the end of 1999 still do and ask ``What's taking
so long?'' (McKenna, Atlanta Journal-Constitution)

   ENTERTAINEMTN/ARTS

   SLEAZY-ROCK _Just when we thought we'd seen and heard
everything, along comes Spin magazine, whose October cover carries
the headline (in barfy neon green, no less), ``The 100 Sleaziest
Moments in Rock.'' The mind boggles, wondering what the editors
might pick from the unspeakably vast pantheon of potential
candidates. (Rollins, Dayton Daily News)

   TV _ Review of ``Grosse Pointe,'' new TV show on WGN. And
today's Hollywood lesson: Don't mess with Aaron Spelling. The
legendary producer may be about 125 years old, but he still wields
clout in Tinseltown. (Thompson, Palm Beach Post) MOVED.

   FALL-TV _ As the presidential campaign shifts into final gear,
the new TV season gets under way. You've probably noticed that
summer rerun season has been especially long this year _ an unhappy
situation necessitated by the late-arriving Summer Olympics. We've
slogged through ``Survivor,'' muddled through ``Who Wants to Be a
Millionaire'' and a few reality also-rans. Now it's time to get
down to business, the prime-time entertainment business, with real
series written by real writers and starring real actors. A look at
what's coming this fall. (Holloway, Austin American-Statesman)
MOVED.

   TORONTO-FESTIVAL _ An overview of the film festival. (Larsen,
Dayton Daily News)

   E-ARTS _ News about the arts on the Internet. (Staff, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution)

   DENZEL _ (TENTATIVE) Q and A with Denzel Washington about making
``Remember The Titans.'' (Longino, Atlanta Journal-Constitution)

   WHERES-THE-SCRIPT _ If you learn one thing from this summer's
recent slate of lackluster movies, learn this: ``Hollywood just
doesn't get it.'' We've had three months of blaring soundtracks
(``Coyote Ugly''), bragadocious special effects (``Hollow Man'')
and more pounding waves of water(``The Perfect Storm'') than anyone
should endure in a lifetime. But in all that hype, where was the
story? That's what Robert McKee wants to know. McKee, a longtime
scriptwriter and instructor, came to Atlanta recently for a
special, intensive 3-day lecture on scriptwriting. We talk to him _
and his students _ about the state of filmmaking, the recent summer
doldrums and what makes a solid, got-to-see-it movie. (Longino,
Atlanta Journal-Constitution)

   PLAYWRIGHT _ A conversation with Pulitzer Prize-winning
playwright Donald Margulies, whose ``Dinner With Friends'' is in
the midst of a monthlong run at the Alliance Theatre. He talks
about what it's like to win the Pulitzer, where DWF came from,
adapting Tom Wolfe's Atlanta-set ``A Man in Full'' for NBC,
playwrighting, middle age and much more. (Janich, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution)

   NY-STAGE-PREVIEW _ New York and regional season preview (short
intro and bulleted items) pegged to 9/26 previews of ``Full
Monty,'' the Broadway musical. (Hulbert, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution)

   BOOKS

   COXNET BOOKS _ (EDS: This is the CoxNet Books page for the
current week. This layout is now available.)

   BOOKS-FANNY _ Review of Catherine Clinton's biography ``Fanny
Kemble's Civil Wars.'' (Fanny, Atlanta Journal-Constitution)

   BOOKS-CHERRY _ Review of Mary Karr's memoir, ``Cherry,'' the
anxiously awaited sequel to her best-selling ``Liar's Club.''
(Pearson, Atlanta Journal-Constitution)

   BOOK-BLONDES _ Review of Candace Bushnell's novel ``Four
Blondes.'' (Atlanta Journal-Constitution)

   SKUBE-ON-BOOKS _ On Barbara Robinette Moss' memoir, ``Change Me
Into Zeus's Daughter,'' about growing up in deep poverty in
Alabama. (Skube, Atlanta Journal-Constitution) FOR SUNDAY

   BOOKS_FOAM _ Emory prof Sidney Perkowitz is nuts about foam. He
looks at a cup of capuccino and sees the structure of the early
universe. Now he's written a book about it, called, as one might
expect, ``Universal Foam.'' (Earle, Atlanta Journal-Constitution)

   SPORTS

   BASEBALL

   BBO-SPORTSCASTER _ Skip Caray, the son of legend Harry Caray,
was born to be a baseball broadcaster. Pete Van Wieren was born to
be anything but. The native of Rochester, N.Y., was in a rock band
and his only college sport was bowling. But Van Wieren has been
with Caray for 25 years as the voices of the Braves. The man they
call ``The Professor'' is the anit-Caray. (Wilkinson, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution) WITH PHOTOS

   FOOTBALL

   PROS

   FBN-KURTWARNER _ If anyone thought the Rams quarterback Kurt
Warner would be a one-year wonder, take a look at the start he has
had this year. Last year's league MVP is once again leading the NFL
in passing and has led the Rams to an unbeaten record. His story as
a former Arena League player was well-chronicled last year as he
led the Rams to a Super Bowl victory. Now, he's back and appears
stronger than ever. (Sugiura, Atlanta Journal-Constitution)

   FBN-COWBOYS _ Previewing the Dallas vs. San Francisco NFL game.
Now that Dallas has won its first game, the Cowboys seek
consistency. The next test is the once-powerful San Francisco
49ers. (Cantu, Austin American-Statesman)

   CUBA-JOURNAL _ VARADERO, Cuba _ A golf vacation in Cuba: Now
there's a contradiction in terms for many baby-boomers, who spent
their elementary school years in the 1960s ducking under their
desks for nuclear attack drills during the Cuban missile crisis.
But the land that once threatened us with Russian nukes has built
its first modern 18-hole golf course at the tourist resort of
Varadero, and hopes Americans will soon be playing the sport of
capitalist bankers on its socialist shores. We play a round and
reflect on the study in contrasts that is modern Cuba. (Williams,
Cox News Service) WITH PHOTOS.

   EDS: This foreign journal can twin with CUBA-EMBARGO.

   CHINA-SEX _ BEIJING _ Prostitution is rampant in China. From the
biggest cities to the smallest towns, from the toniest hotels to
the seediest roadside stalls, women are making a living with their
bodies. Experts say it is one of the major reasons for a
skyrocketing number of cases of syphilis, gonorrhea and other
sexually transmitted diseases (STDs). Although the government is
starting to recognize the seriousness of the problem, few believe
it will be brought under control anytime soon. With an ever-more
mobile population, a dismal level of sex education for young people
who are becoming increasingly sexually active and a sex industry
that is almost institutionalized, government efforts to limit the
spread of STDs seem like a drop in the bucket. (Chao, Cox News
Service) WITH PHOTOS

   SEIRRALEONE _ Greenville, N.C., families urge Congress to visit
with delegation coming from civil war-torn Seirra Leone. The
delegation, including several children, are coming to the U.S. next
week to urge the U.S. to send troops to that country to stop the
war. One of the locals is a new citizen who's working the
democratic process to raise awareness about the war. A good subplot
is that he is acting on his citizenship more than many of us here
who are natives. (Greenville Daily Reflector)

   FLOOD _ Greenville N.C.'s Neighborhood Services division wants
owners of flood damaged property to clean up their lots. A lot of
neighbors who have fixed up their homes are complaining about the
mess. Many offenders are awaiting buyout funds. Should they be
forced to clean up property that's in limbo because of the slow
wheels of government? (Greenville Daily Relector) WITH PHOTO

   CHARTER-SCHOOLS _ WASHINGTON _ Charter schools have crossed the
threshold from ``experimental'' to a real educational phenomenon.
There has been a sharp increase in the number of charter schools
and many more are in the works. Still, they represent only one of
every 45 schools and the jury is out on whether they provide a
better education. Plus, there's heated discussion over who should
license and licensing standards. (Mollison, Cox News Service) WITH
PHOTOS.

   VOTERS-UNINFORMED _ WASHINGTON _ In a survey of college
freshean, the New York Times found ``a striking ingorance of even
the most elementary aspects'' of U.S. politics. The year was 1943.
More than half a century later, amid the ongoing information boom,
social scientists say little has changed. American voters are
disturbingly ignorant about the country's political life and its
leaders. Even in the age of radio talk shows and Internet chat, a
majority of Americans have trouble identifying their congressman or
naming specific policy details of the presidential candidates. A
look at the phenomenon and its impact of voter apathy and turnout.
(Holmes, Cox News Service)

machines. When Gateway introduces the first of its so-called

   (For Atlanta) TECH-GADEL _ WASHINGTON _ As high-tech companies
mushroom, Georgia's old economy - largely built on peanuts, poultry
and pulp wood - is being transformed. The new foundation rests on
computer bits, bytes and biotech. While only about 4 percent of
Georgians are farmers today, about 7 percent are high-tech workers,
such as computer engineers and programmers. In metro Atlanta alone,
roughly 10,000 tech companies employ about 220,000 people. But
while the tech sector is driving up the state's population and
wealth, Georgia's 13-member delegation to Congress remains outside
the inner circles of tech political power. Though they won't speak
on the record, many of Georgia's business executives and lobbyists
grumble about their lawmakers' lackluster leadership on tech
issues. (Geewax, Cox News Service)

   FLIGHT-SERV _ When Todd Bottorff was brought in to help pull
Flightserv.com out of its dive in late May, he faced some
Internet-sized challenges. The Atlanta company's stock had dropped
90 percent from its 52-week high, after ranking as Georgia's
best-performing stock last year. A New York money manager had
cancelled the second half of a $10 million investment. Few business
travelers were using Flightserv's Web site, www.flightserv.com.,
which offers individual seats on private jet flights between
Atlanta and New York. And the company was running out of cash. So,
over the next several weeks, Flightserv's new president and chief
operating officer cut the staff and marketing budget and suspended
flights. Bottorff also plunged into retooling Flightserv's business
model and rounding up new investors and business partners.
(Grantham, Atlanta Journal-Constitution)

   GARCIA-COLUMN _ Political memories are notoriously short, a
Republican friend reminded me during a conversation about Gov.
George W. Bush's current situation. After the primaries,
experienced politicos never expected the race to be anything other
than close. But then Bush caught a good bounce after the Republican
convention in Philadelphia and suddenly was portrayed as inevitable
in the national press, which now leads to stories about how badly
the campaign is stumbling. (Garcia, Austin American-Statesman)

   KLEINBERG-COLUMN _ MIAMI _ If you leave by speedboat from the
environs of Havana and set a course due north, you'll shortly reach
one of an atoll-like group of uninhabited islands called the
Marquesas Keys. They are part of the United States, between Key
West and the Dry Tortugas. You land there, you're in America.
You've succeeded, according to Bill Clinton's controversial wet
foot/dry foot Cuban Adjustment Act, in reaching our shores and
almost assuredly will not be repatriated. Therefore, more and more
are headed for the Marquesas as that is the shortest distance
between Cuba and the United States, about 80 miles. (Kleinberg, Cox
News Service.) MOVES THURSDAY.

   GLASS-COLUMN _ WASHINGTON _ If the Texas governor were running
for ``Mr. Nice Guy,'' you would have to grade his effort as an
``A,'' as in affable, amenable, amiable and amicable. But is that
an adequate argument to assume the presidency in 2001? Once, Bush
glowed in the aura of an invincible winner. But that ended in the
dog days of August and it's unlikely to return even if he manages,
against high odds, to stitch together the 270 electoral votes he
needs to win. (Glass), Cox News Service).

   ELECTRIC-POOCH _ Electronic puppies won't shed, won't bite,
won't chase cars and if you forget to take them out for a walk they
won't do anything unpleasant on the floor. Several toy makers
apparently think interactive electronic puppies are going to be the
next big fad for kids, and they've rushed quite a few models onto
toy department shelves this year. (Cummings, Dayton Daily News)

   SAVING-CAVES _ Rusty's Cave is as quiet as a tomb and as artful
as a museum. As long as the clumsy, the malevolent or the profane
don't stumble upon it, it's safe. For Rusty's, while not a secret,
is not well known, which has protected the formations growing from
the floor and the ceiling. They took thousands of years to form.
They can shatter in seconds. In the darkness, Diane Cousineau of
Lafayette and Bill Putnam of Lawrenceville murmur about enjoying
quiet moments in the cool embrace of the earth. ``You know how some
people are beautiful and stunning and others are just as plain as
plain can be?'' Cousineau says. ``Caves are like that too. Every
one is different.'' Putnam is a director the Atlanta-based
Southeastern Cave Conservancy Inc., which Cousineau chairs. For the
past several years, the 600-member organization has rapidly
acquired caverns from West Virginia to Florida both to hold and to
protect. Most are near Tennessee-Alabama-Georgia border, a region
with perhaps more caves per square mile than anywhere in the United
States. ``Land acquisition is our mission,'' says Cousineau. ``We
just need to go out and buy most of the Southeast. It's a modest
goal.'' (Visser, Atlanta Journal-Constitution) WITH PHOTOS

   TRAVEL-FIRSTCOAST _ That well-traveled ribbon of asphalt known
as A1A _ which follows Florida's Atlantic coastline south all the
way to Key West _ takes on a different identity between Amelia
Island and St. Augustine. Here, the highway is known as the
Buccaneer Trail, and it makes a beeline into the past. The 52-mile
route where pirates, explorers and early settlers once roamed is as
scenic as it is historic. Florida's northeastern coast - including
the booming city of Jacksonville 10 miles inland on the St. Johns
River - offers Atlantans many vacation options within an easy drive
of each other. (Thrasher, Atlanta Journal-Constitution)

   TIME-SHARE _ It can be hard to say no to a timeshare salesman.
You are spending a weekend, gratis, at a resort, sometimes with
spending money or half-price Disney World or dinner theater tickets
thrown in to boot. There is an obligation to at least listen to the
presentation, and the salesmen have a quick retort for every reason
not to buy. But the salesmen probably never mention the inevitable
day when you try to sell the timeshare. Then you may find that your
vacation adventure has turned into a financial nightmare. The
Internet, however, is providing some relief. (Beasley, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution)

   ALABAMA _If you've been through Birmingham lately, you might
have noticed something odd about the skyline. Vulcan has vamoosed.
The cast-iron statue that for six decades crowned the ridge
overlooking downtown has been dismantled for safety reasons. Like
Humpty Dumpty, the Roman god of the forge sits in pieces behind a
fence in Vulcan Park, awaiting the funds to repair his parts and
put him back together again. ``It's got to be the world's largest
derriere,'' says Stewart Dansby, executive director of the Vulcan
Park Foundation, mentioning the bare metal bum that has spawned
many a joke and ``Buns of Iron'' T-shirt. ``We've had more than one
person kiss it.'' Must be an Alabama thing. (Auchmutey, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution)

   FERTILITY _ Recent birth of sextuplets in Greenville, N.C.,
focuses international debate about the use of fertilty drugs in
eastern North Carolina. What medical experts, religious leaders,
academic authorities _ and hopefully the parents _ think about the
fertility drug pros and cons. The growing use of such drugs is
increasing the chances of multiple births like the once here, in
Iowa and Italy. Do such pregnancies unnecessarily risk the babies'
lives? Do they place unnecessary financial and emotional strain on
the families and communities that support them? Are such risks and
strains acceptable in the face of infertility? (Greenville Daily
Reflector)

   POLIO _ This summer, world health officials - including the CDC
- acknowledged they would not meet an oft-stated goal of ridding
the world of polio by the end of this year. Next week, (Sept. 27),
many of those officials leading the fight will join Ted Turner and
other big spenders who are helping to fund the effort, in a ``polio
summit'' to explore why the fight is not being won on time. The NYC
meeting is intended to redirect attention away from the
public-health failure and focus media attention on the last push to
eradicate polio - which WHO hopes to accomplish shortly. To set up
the conference, we take a look at why 15-20 of the 30 countries
which had polio at the end of 1999 still do and ask ``What's taking
so long?'' (McKenna, Atlanta Journal-Constitution)

   WHERES-THE-SCRIPT _ If you learn one thing from this summer's
recent slate of lackluster movies, learn this: ``Hollywood just
doesn't get it.'' We've had three months of blaring soundtracks
(``Coyote Ugly''), bragadocious special effects (``Hollow Man'')
and more pounding waves of water(``The Perfect Storm'') than anyone
should endure in a lifetime. But in all that hype, where was the
story? That's what Robert McKee wants to know. McKee, a longtime
scriptwriter and instructor, came to Atlanta recently for a
special, intensive 3-day lecture on scriptwriting. We talk to him _
